column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Hilarius spoke gently : —

#Text=“ It is indeed a grievous sin against God and His Church to live together out of holy wedlock , and perchance ’ tis true that for this very thing thou hast been afflicted , even as David the great King .
#Text=But since thou didst sin ignorantly the Lord in His mercy sent me to serve thee in thy sore need ; ay , and in very truth , Our Lady herself showed me where the coney lay snared .
#Text=Let us pray God by His dear Mother to forgive us our sins and to have mercy on these little ones . ”
#Text=And kneeling there in the firelight he besought the great Father for his new-found family .
#Text=Five days passed , and despite extreme care victuals were short .

#Text=Hilarius dug up roots from the hedgerows , and went hungry , but at last the pinch came ; the woman was too weak and ill to walk , the babe scarce in life — there could be no thought of flight — and the little maid grew white , and wan and silent .
#Text=Then it came to Hilarius that he would once again beg food in the village where he had sought help before .
#Text=He went slowly , for he had eaten little that his maid might be the better fed , and he was very sad .
#Text=When he reached the village he found his errand like to be vain .
#Text=News of the Plague was coming from many parts , and each man feared for his own skin .
#Text=At every house they questioned him :
#Text=“ Art thou from a hamlet where the Plague hath been ? ” and when he answered “ Yea , ” the door was shut .
#Text=Very soon men , angry and afraid , came to drive him from the place .
#Text=He gained the village cross , and prayed them for love of the Saviour and His holy Rood to give him bread for his little maid and her mother .
#Text=Let them set it in the street , he would take it and cross no man ’s threshold .
#Text=Surely they could not ; for shame , let a little child die of want ?
#Text=“ Nay , ’ tis better they die , so are we safe , ” cried a voice ; then they fell upon him and beat him , and drove him from the village with blows and curses .
#Text=Bruised and panting , he ran from them , and at last the chase ceased ; breathless and exhausted he flung himself under a hedge .
#Text=A hawk swooped , struck near him , and rose again with its prey .
#Text=Hilarius shuddered ; but perhaps the hawk had nestlings waiting open-mouthed for food ?
#Text=His little maid !
#Text=His eyes filled with tears as he thought of those who awaited him .
#Text=He picked up a stone , and watched if perchance a coney might show itself .
#Text=He had never killed , but were not his nestlings agape ?
#Text=Nothing stirred , but along the road came a waggon of strange shape and gaily painted .
#Text=He rose to his feet , praying the great Mother to send him help in his awful need .
#Text=The waggon drew near ; the driver sat asleep upon the shaft , the horse took his own pace .
#Text=It passed him before he could pluck up heart to ask an alms , and from the back dangled a small sack and a hen .
#Text=If he begged and was refused his little maid must die .

#Text=A minute later the sack and the hen had changed owners — but not unobserved ; a clear voice called a halt ; the waggon stood fast ; two figures sprang out , a girl and a boy : and Hilarius stood before them on the white highway — a thief .
#Text=“ Seize the knave ! ” cried the girl sharply .
#Text=Hilarius stared at her and she at him .
#Text=It was his dancer , and she knew him , ay , despite the change of dress and scene , she knew him .
#Text=“ What !
#Text=The worthy novice turned worldling and thief ! Nay , ’ tis a rare jest .
#Text=What of thy fine sermons now , good preacher ? ”
#Text=But Hilarius answered never a word ; overcome by shame , grief , and hunger , sudden darkness fell upon him .
#Text=When he came to himself he was sitting propped against the hedge ; the waggon was drawn up by the roadside , and the dancer and her brother stood watching him .
#Text=“ Fetch bread and wine , ” said the girl , and to Hilarius who tried to speak , “ Peace , ’ til thou hast eaten . ”
#Text=Hilarius ate eagerly , and when he had made an end the dancer said : —
#Text=“ Now tell thy tale .
#Text=Prithee , since when didst thou leave thy Saints and thy nursery for such an ill trade as this ? ”
#Text=Hilarius told her all , and when he had finished he wept because of his little maid , and his were not the only tears .
#Text=The dancer went to the waggon and came back with much food taken from her store , to which she added the hen ; the sack held but fodder .
#Text=“ But , Gia , ” grumbled her brother , “ there will be naught for us to-night . ”
#Text=“ Thou canst eat bread , or else go hungry , ” she retorted , and filled a small sack with the victuals .
#Text=Hilarius watched her , hardly daring to hope .
#Text=She held it out to him :
#Text=“ Now up and off to thy little maid . ”
#Text=Hilarius took the sack , but only to lay it down again .
#Text=Kneeling , he took both her little brown hands , and his tears fell fast as he kissed them .
#Text=“ Maid , maid , canst forgive my theft , ay , and my hard words in the forest ?
#Text=God help me for a poor , blind fool ! ”
